name: The unique solution to x * A034444(x) = A383276(n).
comment: a(n) is the single divisor d of A383276(n) such that d * A034444(d) = A383276(n).
A permutation of the positive integers: the positive integers k sort by the value of k * A034444(k).
link: Amiram Eldar, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
Index entries for sequences that are permutations of the natural numbers.
mathematica: s[k_] := Module[{ds = Divisors[k], ans = Nothing}, Do[If[2^PrimeNu[d]*d == k, ans = d; Break[]], {d, ds}]; ans]; Array[s, 300]
s[k_] := Module[{e = IntegerExponent[k, 2], o, om}, o = k/2^e; om = PrimeNu[o]; If[e == om, o, If[e > om + 1, 2^(e-om-1) * o, Nothing]]]; Array[s, 300]
program: (PARI) list(lim) = for(k = 1, lim, fordiv(k, d, if((1 << omega(d)) * d == k, print1(d, ", "); break)));
(PARI) list(lim) = {my(e, o, om); for(k = 1, lim, e = valuation(k, 2); o = k >> e; om = omega(o); if(e == om, print1(o, ", "), if(e > om + 1, print1((1 << (e-om-1)) * o, ", "))));}
author: _Amiram Eldar_, Apr 21 2025

name: Numbers of the form A034444(k) * k.
comment: Numbers m that have a divisor d such that A034444(d) * d = m.
All the terms above 1 are even since A034444(k) is even for k >= 2.
A number m is a term if and only if either A007814(m) = A005087(m) or A007814(m) > A005087(m) + 1.
link: Amiram Eldar, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
H. L. Abbott and M. V. Subbarao, On the Distribution of the Sequence {nd*(n)}, Canadian Mathematical Bulletin , Vol. 32 , No. 1 (1989), pp. 105-108.
mathematica: q[k_] := Module[{e = IntegerExponent[k, 2], w}, w = PrimeNu[k/2^e]; e > w + 1 || e == w]; Select[Range[200], q]
program: (PARI) isok(k) = fordiv(k, d, if((1 << omega(d)) * d == k, return(1))); 0;
(PARI) isok(k) = {my(e = valuation(k, 2), w = omega(k >> e)); e > w + 1 || e == w;}
xref: Cf. A005087, A007814, A034444, A298473, A383277 (characteristic function), A383278 (number of terms not exceeding n), A383279.
author: _Amiram Eldar_, Apr 21 2025

name: The number of divisors d of n for which A034444(d)*d is equal to n.
comment: The number of these divisors is either 0 or 1.
link: Amiram Eldar, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
H. L. Abbott and M. V. Subbarao, On the Distribution of the Sequence {nd*(n)}, Canadian Mathematical Bulletin , Vol. 32 , No. 1 (1989), pp. 105-108.
formula: a(n) = 1 if either A007814(n) = A005087(n) or A007814(n) > A005087(n) + 1, and 0 otherwise.
mathematica: a[n_] := Module[{e = IntegerExponent[n, 2], w}, w = PrimeNu[n/2^e]; If[e > w + 1 || e == w, 1, 0]]; Array[a, 100]
program: (PARI) a(n) = sumdiv(n, d, (1 << omega(d)) * d == n);
(PARI) a(n) = {my(e = valuation(n, 2), w = omega(n >> e)); e > w + 1 || e == w;}
author: _Amiram Eldar_, Apr 21 2025

name: The number of integers k such that A034444(k) * k <= n.
comment: The number of terms of A383276 not exceeding n.
reference: József Sándor, Dragoslav S. Mitrinovic, and Borislav Crstici, Handbook of Number Theory I, Springer Science & Business Media, 2005, Chapter II, section 31, page 72.
link: Amiram Eldar, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
H. L. Abbott and M. V. Subbarao, On the Distribution of the Sequence {nd*(n)}, Canadian Mathematical Bulletin , Vol. 32 , No. 1 (1989), pp. 105-108.
formula: a(n) = (c + o(1)) * n / sqrt(log(n)), where c = (1/sqrt(Pi)) * Product_{p prime} (p-1/2)/sqrt(p*(p-1)) = A087197 * A345288 = 0.61890644913204789046... (Abbott and Subbarao, 1989).
mathematica: f[n_] := Module[{e = IntegerExponent[n, 2], w}, w = PrimeNu[n/2^e]; If[e > w + 1 || e == w, 1, 0]]; Accumulate[Array[f, 100]]
program: (PARI) list(lim) = my(s = 0); for(n = 1, lim, s += sumdiv(n, d, (1 << omega(d)) * d == n); print1(s, ", "));
(PARI) f(n) = {my(e = valuation(n, 2), w = omega(n >> e)); e > w + 1 || e == w;}
list(lim) = my(s = 0); for(n = 1, lim, s += f(n); print1(s, ", "));
author: _Amiram Eldar_, Apr 21 2025
